Status Severity Service Name Region Check ID Check Title Resource ID Resource Tags Status Extended Risk Recomendation Compliance
FAIL low accessanalyzer ap-northeast-1 accessanalyzer_enabled Check if IAM Access Analyzer is enabled 051355080838 IAM Access Analyzer in account 051355080838 is not enabled

AWS IAM Access Analyzer helps you identify the resources in your organization and accounts, such as Amazon S3 buckets or IAM roles, that are shared with an external entity. This lets you identify unintended access to your resources and data, which is a security risk. IAM Access Analyzer uses a form of mathematical analysis called automated reasoning, which applies logic and mathematical inference to determine all possible access paths allowed by a resource policy.

Enable IAM Access Analyzer for all accounts, create analyzer and take action over it is recommendations (IAM Access Analyzer is available at no additional cost).

•CIS-1.5: 1.20 •CIS-1.4: 1.20

•CIS-1.5: 1.20 •CIS-1.4: 1.20

INFO medium account us-east-1 account_maintain_current_contact_details Maintain current contact details. 051355080838 Manual check: Login to the AWS Console. Choose your account name on the top right of the window -> My Account -> Contact Information.

Ensure contact email and telephone details for AWS accounts are current and map to more than one individual in your organization. An AWS account supports a number of contact details; and AWS will use these to contact the account owner if activity judged to be in breach of Acceptable Use Policy. If an AWS account is observed to be behaving in a prohibited or suspicious manner; AWS will attempt to contact the account owner by email and phone using the contact details listed. If this is unsuccessful and the account behavior needs urgent mitigation; proactive measures may be taken; including throttling of traffic between the account exhibiting suspicious behavior and the AWS API endpoints and the Internet. This will result in impaired service to and from the account in question.

Using the Billing and Cost Management console complete contact details.

•CIS-1.5: 1.1 •CIS-1.4: 1.1 •ENS-RD2022: op.ext.7.aws.am.1

INFO medium account us-east-1 account_security_contact_information_is_registered Ensure security contact information is registered. 051355080838 Manual check: Login to the AWS Console. Choose your account name on the top right of the window -> My Account -> Alternate Contacts -> Security Section.

AWS provides customers with the option of specifying the contact information for accounts security team. It is recommended that this information be provided. Specifying security-specific contact information will help ensure that security advisories sent by AWS reach the team in your organization that is best equipped to respond to them.

Go to the My Account section and complete alternate contacts.

•CIS-1.5: 1.2 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: account, acm •CIS-1.4: 1.2 •ENS-RD2022: op.ext.7.aws.am.1

INFO medium account us-east-1 account_security_questions_are_registered_in_the_aws_account Ensure security questions are registered in the AWS account. 051355080838 Manual check: Login to the AWS Console as root. Choose your account name on the top right of the window -> My Account -> Configure Security Challenge Questions.

The AWS support portal allows account owners to establish security questions that can be used to authenticate individuals calling AWS customer service for support. It is recommended that security questions be established. When creating a new AWS account a default super user is automatically created. This account is referred to as the root account. It is recommended that the use of this account be limited and highly controlled. During events in which the root password is no longer accessible or the MFA token associated with root is lost/destroyed it is possible through authentication using secret questions and associated answers to recover root login access.

Login as root account and from My Account configure Security questions.

•CIS-1.5: 1.3 •CIS-1.4: 1.3 •ENS-RD2022: op.ext.7.aws.am.1

FAIL low cloudtrail ap-northeast-1 cloudtrail_cloudwatch_logging_enabled Ensure CloudTrail trails are integrated with CloudWatch Logs management-events Multiregion trail management-events is not logging in the last 24h

Sending CloudTrail logs to CloudWatch Logs will facilitate real-time and historic activity logging based on user; API; resource; and IP address; and provides opportunity to establish alarms and notifications for anomalous or sensitivity account activity.

Validate that the trails in CloudTrail has an arn set in the CloudWatchLogsLogGroupArn property.

FAIL low cloudtrail ap-northeast-2 cloudtrail_cloudwatch_logging_enabled Ensure CloudTrail trails are integrated with CloudWatch Logs management-events Multiregion trail management-events is not logging in the last 24h

Sending CloudTrail logs to CloudWatch Logs will facilitate real-time and historic activity logging based on user; API; resource; and IP address; and provides opportunity to establish alarms and notifications for anomalous or sensitivity account activity.

FAIL low cloudtrail ap-south-1 cloudtrail_cloudwatch_logging_enabled Ensure CloudTrail trails are integrated with CloudWatch Logs management-events Multiregion trail management-events is not logging in the last 24h

Sending CloudTrail logs to CloudWatch Logs will facilitate real-time and historic activity logging based on user; API; resource; and IP address; and provides opportunity to establish alarms and notifications for anomalous or sensitivity account activity.

Validate that the trails in CloudTrail has an arn set in the CloudWatchLogsLogGroupArn property.

Sending CloudTrail logs to CloudWatch Logs will facilitate real-time and historic activity logging based on user; API; resource; and IP address; and provides opportunity to establish alarms and notifications for anomalous or sensitivity account activity.

Validate that the trails in CloudTrail has an arn set in the CloudWatchLogsLogGroupArn property.

•SOC2: cc_7_2, cc_7_3, cc_a_1_2 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-4, ac-2-g, au-2-a-d, au-3, au-6-1-3, au-7-1, au-12-a-c, si-4-a-b-c •CIS-1.5: 3.4 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: cloudtrail •CIS-1.4: 3.4 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2_4, ac_2, au_2, au_3, au_6_1, au_6_3, au_7_1, au_12, ca_7, si_4_2, si_4_4, si_4_5, si_4 •FFIEC: d2-is-is-b-1, d2-ma-ma-b-1, d2-ma-ma-b-2, d3-dc-an-b-3, d3-dc-an-b-4, d3-dc-an-b-5, d3-dc-ev-b-1, d3-pc-im-b-3, d3-pc-im-b-7, d5-dr-de-b-3 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_3_1, 3_3_2, 3_3_3, 3_3_5, 3_6_1, 3_6_2, 3_12_4 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_4, ac_3_1, ac_3_10, ac_4_26, ac_6_9, au_2_b, au_3_a, au_3_b, au_3_c, au_3_d, au_3_e, au_3_f, au_4_1, au_6_1, au_6_3, au_6_4, au_6_5, au_6_6, au_6_9, au_7_1, au_8_b, au_9_7, au_10, au_12_a, au_12_c, au_12_1, au_12_2, au_12_3, au_12_4, au_14_a, au_14_b, au_14_3, au_16, ca_7_b, cm_5_1_b, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, ia_3_3_b, ma_4_1_a, pm_14_a_1, pm_14_b, pm_31, sc_7_9_b, si_1_1_c, si_3_8_b, si_4_2, si_4_17, si_4_20, si_7_8, si_10_1_c •PCI-3.2.1: cloudtrail •GDPR: article_25, article_30 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ae_1, ae_3, cm_2, cm_5, cp_4, ra_5, sc_4, pt_1 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.r1.aws.ct.7, op.mon.3.aws.cwl.2 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_4 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-e, 11.10-k, 11.300-d •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_d, 164_308_a_6_ii, 164_312_b, 164_312_e_2_i

PASS medium cloudtrail ap-northeast-1 cloudtrail_kms_encryption_enabled Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs management-events Multiregion trail management-events has encryption enabled

By default; the log files delivered by CloudTrail to your bucket are encrypted by Amazon server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3). To provide a security layer that is directly manageable; you can instead use server-side encryption with AWS KMS–managed keys (SSE-KMS) for your CloudTrail log files.

This approach has the following advantages: You can create and manage the CMK encryption keys yourself. You can use a single CMK to encrypt and decrypt log files for multiple accounts across all regions. You have control over who can use your key for encrypting and decrypting CloudTrail log files. You can assign permissions for the key to the users. You have enhanced security.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: au-9, sc-28 •CIS-1.5: 3.7 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: cloudtrail •CIS-1.4: 3.7 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: au_9, sc_28 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_3_8, 3_13_11, 3_13_16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: au_9_3, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, cp_9_d, sc_8_3, sc_8_4, sc_13_a, sc_28_1, si_19_4 •PCI-3.2.1: cloudtrail •GDPR: article_25, article_30, article_32 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-1 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ds_1 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.7 •GxP-EU-Annex-11: 7.1-data-storage-damage-protection •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-c, 11.30 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_1_ii_d, 164_308_a_4_ii_a, 164_312_a_2_iv, 164_312_c_1, 164_312_c_2, 164_312_e_2_ii •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: au-9

PASS medium cloudtrail ap-northeast-2 cloudtrail_kms_encryption_enabled Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs management-events Multiregion trail management-events has encryption enabled

By default; the log files delivered by CloudTrail to your bucket are encrypted by Amazon server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3). To provide a security layer that is directly manageable; you can instead use server-side encryption with AWS KMS–managed keys (SSE-KMS) for your CloudTrail log files.

This approach has the following advantages: You can create and manage the CMK encryption keys yourself. You can use a single CMK to encrypt and decrypt log files for multiple accounts across all regions. You have control over who can use your key for encrypting and decrypting CloudTrail log files. You can assign permissions for the key to the users. You have enhanced security.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: au-9, sc-28 •CIS-1.5: 3.7 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: cloudtrail •CIS-1.4: 3.7 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: au_9, sc_28 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_3_8, 3_13_11, 3_13_16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: au_9_3, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, cp_9_d, sc_8_3, sc_8_4, sc_13_a, sc_28_1, si_19_4 •PCI-3.2.1: cloudtrail •GDPR: article_25, article_30, article_32 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-1 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ds_1 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.7 •GxP-EU-Annex-11: 7.1-data-storage-damage-protection •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-c, 11.30 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_1_ii_d, 164_308_a_4_ii_a, 164_312_a_2_iv, 164_312_c_1, 164_312_c_2, 164_312_e_2_ii •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: au-9

PASS medium cloudtrail ap-northeast-3 cloudtrail_kms_encryption_enabled Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs management-events Multiregion trail management-events has encryption enabled

By default; the log files delivered by CloudTrail to your bucket are encrypted by Amazon server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3). To provide a security layer that is directly manageable; you can instead use server-side encryption with AWS KMS–managed keys (SSE-KMS) for your CloudTrail log files.

This approach has the following advantages: You can create and manage the CMK encryption keys yourself. You can use a single CMK to encrypt and decrypt log files for multiple accounts across all regions. You have control over who can use your key for encrypting and decrypting CloudTrail log files. You can assign permissions for the key to the users. You have enhanced security.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: au-9, sc-28 •CIS-1.5: 3.7 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: cloudtrail •CIS-1.4: 3.7 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: au_9, sc_28 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_3_8, 3_13_11, 3_13_16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: au_9_3, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, cp_9_d, sc_8_3, sc_8_4, sc_13_a, sc_28_1, si_19_4 •PCI-3.2.1: cloudtrail •GDPR: article_25, article_30, article_32 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-1 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ds_1 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.7 •GxP-EU-Annex-11: 7.1-data-storage-damage-protection •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-c, 11.30 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_1_ii_d, 164_308_a_4_ii_a, 164_312_a_2_iv, 164_312_c_1, 164_312_c_2, 164_312_e_2_ii •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: au-9

By default; the log files delivered by CloudTrail to your bucket are encrypted by Amazon server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3). To provide a security layer that is directly manageable; you can instead use server-side encryption with AWS KMS–managed keys (SSE-KMS) for your CloudTrail log files.

This approach has the following advantages: You can create and manage the CMK encryption keys yourself. You can use a single CMK to encrypt and decrypt log files for multiple accounts across all regions. You have control over who can use your key for encrypting and decrypting CloudTrail log files. You can assign permissions for the key to the users. You have enhanced security.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: au-9, sc-28 •CIS-1.5: 3.7 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: cloudtrail •CIS-1.4: 3.7 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: au_9, sc_28 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_3_8, 3_13_11, 3_13_16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: au_9_3, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, cp_9_d, sc_8_3, sc_8_4, sc_13_a, sc_28_1, si_19_4 •PCI-3.2.1: cloudtrail •GDPR: article_25, article_30, article_32 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-1 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ds_1 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.7 •GxP-EU-Annex-11: 7.1-data-storage-damage-protection •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-c, 11.30 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_1_ii_d, 164_308_a_4_ii_a, 164_312_a_2_iv, 164_312_c_1, 164_312_c_2, 164_312_e_2_ii •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: au-9

PASS medium cloudtrail us-east-2 cloudtrail_kms_encryption_enabled Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs management-events Multiregion trail management-events has encryption enabled

By default; the log files delivered by CloudTrail to your bucket are encrypted by Amazon server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3). To provide a security layer that is directly manageable; you can instead use server-side encryption with AWS KMS–managed keys (SSE-KMS) for your CloudTrail log files.

This approach has the following advantages: You can create and manage the CMK encryption keys yourself. You can use a single CMK to encrypt and decrypt log files for multiple accounts across all regions. You have control over who can use your key for encrypting and decrypting CloudTrail log files. You can assign permissions for the key to the users. You have enhanced security.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: au-9, sc-28 •CIS-1.5: 3.7 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: cloudtrail •CIS-1.4: 3.7 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: au_9, sc_28 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_3_8, 3_13_11, 3_13_16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: au_9_3, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, cp_9_d, sc_8_3, sc_8_4, sc_13_a, sc_28_1, si_19_4 •PCI-3.2.1: cloudtrail •GDPR: article_25, article_30, article_32 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-1 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ds_1 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.7 •GxP-EU-Annex-11: 7.1-data-storage-damage-protection •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-c, 11.30 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_1_ii_d, 164_308_a_4_ii_a, 164_312_a_2_iv, 164_312_c_1, 164_312_c_2, 164_312_e_2_ii •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: au-9

PASS medium cloudtrail us-west-1 cloudtrail_kms_encryption_enabled Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs management-events Multiregion trail management-events has encryption enabled

By default; the log files delivered by CloudTrail to your bucket are encrypted by Amazon server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3). To provide a security layer that is directly manageable; you can instead use server-side encryption with AWS KMS–managed keys (SSE-KMS) for your CloudTrail log files.

This approach has the following advantages: You can create and manage the CMK encryption keys yourself. You can use a single CMK to encrypt and decrypt log files for multiple accounts across all regions. You have control over who can use your key for encrypting and decrypting CloudTrail log files. You can assign permissions for the key to the users. You have enhanced security.

PASS medium cloudtrail ap-northeast-1 cloudtrail_log_file_validation_enabled Ensure CloudTrail log file validation is enabled management-events Multiregion trail management-events log file validation enabled

Enabling log file validation will provide additional integrity checking of CloudTrail logs.

Ensure LogFileValidationEnabled is set to true for each trail.

Enabling log file validation will provide additional integrity checking of CloudTrail logs.

Ensure LogFileValidationEnabled is set to true for each trail.

•SOC2: cc_7_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: au-9, si-7-1, si-7 •CIS-1.5: 3.2 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: cloudtrail •CIS-1.4: 3.2 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: si_7_1, si_7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_3_8, 3_13_1 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: au_9_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, pm_11_b, pm_17_b, sa_1_1, sa_10_1, sc_16_1, si_1_a_2, si_4_d, si_7_1, si_7_3, si_7_7, si_7_a •PCI-3.2.1: cloudtrail •GDPR: article_25, article_32 •CISA: your-systems-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ds_6, ds_7 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.aws.ct.3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-a, 11.30 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_1_ii_d, 164_312_b, 164_312_c_1, 164_312_c_2 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, au-2, au-9

PASS medium cloudtrail us-east-1 cloudtrail_log_file_validation_enabled Ensure CloudTrail log file validation is enabled management-events Multiregion trail management-events log file validation enabled

Enabling log file validation will provide additional integrity checking of CloudTrail logs.

Ensure LogFileValidationEnabled is set to true for each trail.

FAIL medium cloudtrail ap-northeast-1 cloudtrail_logs_s3_bucket_access_logging_enabled Ensure S3 bucket access logging is enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket management-events Trail management-events is delivering logs in a cross-account bucket aws-cloudtrail-logs-130144219161-603fb538 in another account out of Prowler's permissions scope, please check it manually

Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits; help you learn about your customer base; and understand your Amazon S3 bill.

Ensure that S3 buckets have Logging enabled. CloudTrail data events can be used in place of S3 bucket logging. If that is the case; this finding can be considered a false positive.

•CIS-1.5: 3.6 •CIS-1.4: 3.6 •GDPR: article_25 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.r1.aws.ct.6, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.5

PASS critical cloudtrail ap-northeast-1 cloudtrail_logs_s3_bucket_is_not_publicly_accessible Ensure the S3 bucket CloudTrail logs is not publicly accessible management-events Trail management-events bucket (aws-cloudtrail-logs-130144219161-603fb538) is a cross-account bucket in another account out of Prowler's permissions scope, please check it manually

Allowing public access to CloudTrail log content may aid an adversary in identifying weaknesses in the affected accounts use or configuration.

Analyze Bucket policy to validate appropriate permissions. Ensure the AllUsers principal is not granted privileges. Ensure the AuthenticatedUsers principal is not granted privileges.

•CIS-1.5: 3.3 •CIS-1.4: 3.3 •GDPR: article_25 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.2, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.6

Analyze Bucket policy to validate appropriate permissions. Ensure the AllUsers principal is not granted privileges. Ensure the AuthenticatedUsers principal is not granted privileges.

•CIS-1.5: 3.3 •CIS-1.4: 3.3 •GDPR: article_25 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.2, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.6

PASS critical cloudtrail eu-north-1 cloudtrail_logs_s3_bucket_is_not_publicly_accessible Ensure the S3 bucket CloudTrail logs is not publicly accessible management-events Trail management-events bucket (aws-cloudtrail-logs-130144219161-603fb538) is a cross-account bucket in another account out of Prowler's permissions scope, please check it manually

Allowing public access to CloudTrail log content may aid an adversary in identifying weaknesses in the affected accounts use or configuration.

Analyze Bucket policy to validate appropriate permissions. Ensure the AllUsers principal is not granted privileges. Ensure the AuthenticatedUsers principal is not granted privileges.

•CIS-1.5: 3.3 •CIS-1.4: 3.3 •GDPR: article_25 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.2, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.6

•CIS-1.5: 3.3 •CIS-1.4: 3.3 •GDPR: article_25 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.aws.ct.4, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.2, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.6

PASS high cloudtrail ap-northeast-1 cloudtrail_multi_region_enabled Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions management-events Trail management-events is multiregion and it is logging

AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller; the time of the API call; the source IP address of the API caller; the request parameters; and the response elements returned by the AWS service.

Ensure Logging is set to ON on all regions (even if they are not being used at the moment.

PASS high cloudtrail ap-southeast-2 cloudtrail_multi_region_enabled Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions management-events Trail management-events is multiregion and it is logging

AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller; the time of the API call; the source IP address of the API caller; the request parameters; and the response elements returned by the AWS service.

Ensure Logging is set to ON on all regions (even if they are not being used at the moment.

PASS high cloudtrail ca-central-1 cloudtrail_multi_region_enabled Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions management-events Trail management-events is multiregion and it is logging

AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller; the time of the API call; the source IP address of the API caller; the request parameters; and the response elements returned by the AWS service.

Ensure Logging is set to ON on all regions (even if they are not being used at the moment.

PASS high cloudtrail sa-east-1 cloudtrail_multi_region_enabled Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions management-events Trail management-events is multiregion and it is logging

AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller; the time of the API call; the source IP address of the API caller; the request parameters; and the response elements returned by the AWS service.

Ensure Logging is set to ON on all regions (even if they are not being used at the moment.

PASS high cloudtrail us-east-1 cloudtrail_multi_region_enabled Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions management-events Trail management-events is multiregion and it is logging

AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller; the time of the API call; the source IP address of the API caller; the request parameters; and the response elements returned by the AWS service.

Ensure Logging is set to ON on all regions (even if they are not being used at the moment.

FAIL low cloudtrail us-east-1 cloudtrail_s3_dataevents_read_enabled Check if S3 buckets have Object-level logging for read events is enabled in CloudTrail. No trails No CloudTrail trails have a data event to record all S3 object-level API operations.

If logs are not enabled, monitoring of service use and threat analysis is not possible.

Enable logs. Create an S3 lifecycle policy. Define use cases, metrics and automated responses where applicable.

FAIL medium cloudwatch us-east-1 cloudwatch_changes_to_network_acls_alarm_configured Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for changes to Network Access Control Lists (NACL). 051355080838 No CloudWatch log groups found with metric filters or alarms associated.

Monitoring unauthorized API calls will help reveal application errors and may reduce time to detect malicious activity.

Monitoring unauthorized API calls will help reveal application errors and may reduce time to detect malicious activity.

It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for unauthorized requests.

The AWS configuration item history captured by AWS Config enables security analysis, resource change tracking and compliance auditing.

It is recommended to enable AWS Config be enabled in all regions.

•SOC2: cc_2_1, cc_3_1, cc_3_4, cc_8_1 •CIS-1.5: 3.5 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: config •CIS-1.4: 3.5 •PCI-3.2.1: config •GDPR: article_25, article_30 •NIST-CSF-1.1: cm_2, am_1, ra_5, sc_4, ip_12 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.1.aws.cfg.1, op.exp.3.aws.cfg.1, op.exp.3.r3.aws.cfg.1, op.mon.3.r2.aws.cfg.1, op.mon.3.r6.aws.cfg.1 •GxP-EU-Annex-11: 10-change-and-configuration-management, 4.5-validation-development-quality, 4.6-validation-quality-performance •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_a

FAIL medium ec2 ap-southeast-2 ec2_ebs_volume_encryption Ensure there are no EBS Volumes unencrypted. vol-0b22d59e1b18f72ed EBS Snapshot vol-0b22d59e1b18f72ed is unencrypted.

Data encryption at rest prevents data visibility in the event of its unauthorized access or theft.

Encrypt all EBS volumes and Enable Encryption by default You can configure your AWS account to enforce the encryption of the new EBS volumes and snapshot copies that you create. For example; Amazon EBS encrypts the EBS volumes created when you launch an instance and the snapshots that you copy from an unencrypted snapshot.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: sc-28 •CIS-1.5: 2.2.1 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: ec2 •CIS-1.4: 2.2.1 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: sc_28 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-12 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_5_10, 3_13_11, 3_13_16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: au_9_3, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, cp_9_d, sc_8_3, sc_8_4, sc_13_a, sc_28_1, si_19_4 •GDPR: article_32 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-1, your-data-2 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ds_1 •ENS-RD2022: mp.si.2.aws.kms.1 •GxP-EU-Annex-11: 7.1-data-storage-damage-protection •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-g, 11.30 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_a, 164_312_a_2_iv, 164_312_c_1, 164_312_c_2, 164_312_e_2_ii

PASS medium ec2 ap-southeast-2 ec2_instance_profile_attached Ensure IAM instance roles are used for AWS resource access from instances i-0bf1fef8eb0acf371 •aws:cloudformation:stack-name=awseb-e-3uazn9rph8-stack •elasticbeanstalk:environment-id=e-3uazn9rph8 •aws:autoscaling:groupName=awseb-e-3uazn9rph8-stack-AWSEBAutoScalingGroup-1NOPT9EVN7CHE •aws:cloudformation:logical-id=AWSEBAutoScalingGroup •aws:ec2launchtemplate:id=lt-026250bbd7b00cf4c •elasticbeanstalk:environment-name=2-linux2-backend-api-dev •aws:cloudformation:stack-id=arn:aws:cloudformation:ap-southeast-2:051355080838:stack/awseb-e-3uazn9rph8-stack/d1e66b60-6c5d-11ec-b824-0a1c6b610dfc •aws:ec2launchtemplate:version=6 •Name=2-linux2-backend-api-dev EC2 Instance i-0bf1fef8eb0acf371 associated with Instance Profile Role arn:aws:iam::051355080838:instance-profile/aws-elasticbeanstalk-ec2-role.

AWS access from within AWS instances can be done by either encoding AWS keys into AWS API calls or by assigning the instance to a role which has an appropriate permissions policy for the required access. AWS IAM roles reduce the risks associated with sharing and rotating credentials that can be used outside of AWS itself. If credentials are compromised, they can be used from outside of the AWS account.

Create an IAM instance role if necessary and attach it to the corresponding EC2 instance..

•CIS-1.5: 1.18 •CIS-1.4: 1.18 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_3, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g

•CIS-1.5: 1.18 •CIS-1.4: 1.18 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_3, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g

FAIL medium ec2 ap-northeast-1 ec2_networkacl_allow_ingress_any_port Ensure no Network ACLs allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 to any port. acl-9519d2f3 Network ACL acl-9519d2f3 has every port open to the Internet.

Even having a perimeter firewall, having network acls open allows any user or malware with vpc access to scan for well known and sensitive ports and gain access to instance.

Apply Zero Trust approach. Implement a process to scan and remediate unrestricted or overly permissive network acls. Recommended best practices is to narrow the definition for the minimum ports required.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-4, ac-17-1, ac-21-b, cm-2, sc-4, sc-7-3, sc-7 •CIS-1.5: 5.1 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: ec2 •CIS-1.4: 5.1 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_4, cm_2, sc_7_3, sc_7 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-10, d3-pc-im-b-1, d3-pc-im-b-2, d3-pc-im-b-6, d4-c-co-b-2 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_3, 3_1_14, 3_1_20, 3_4_1, 3_4_7, 3_13_1, 3_13_2, 3_13_5, 3_13_6 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_4_21, ac_17_b, ac_17_1, ac_17_4_a, ac_17_9, ac_17_10, cm_2_a, cm_2_2, cm_6_a, cm_7_b, cm_8_6, cm_9_b, sc_7_5, sc_7_7, sc_7_11, sc_7_12, sc_7_16, sc_7_21, sc_7_24_b, sc_7_25, sc_7_26, sc_7_27, sc_7_28, sc_7_a, sc_7_c •CISA: your-data-2 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ae_1, ac_3, ac_5, pt_4 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3, annex_i_5_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g, 11.10-k •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_312_e_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-17, cm-2, sc-7

Even having a perimeter firewall, having network acls open allows any user or malware with vpc access to scan for well known and sensitive ports and gain access to instance.

Apply Zero Trust approach. Implement a process to scan and remediate unrestricted or overly permissive network acls. Recommended best practices is to narrow the definition for the minimum ports required.

Even having a perimeter firewall, having network acls open allows any user or malware with vpc access to scan for well known and sensitive ports and gain access to instance.

Apply Zero Trust approach. Implement a process to scan and remediate unrestricted or overly permissive network acls. Recommended best practices is to narrow the definition for the minimum ports required.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-4, ac-17-1, ac-21-b, cm-2, sc-4, sc-7-3, sc-7 •CIS-1.5: 5.1 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: ec2 •CIS-1.4: 5.1 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_4, cm_2, sc_7_3, sc_7 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-10, d3-pc-im-b-1, d3-pc-im-b-2, d3-pc-im-b-6, d4-c-co-b-2 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_3, 3_1_14, 3_1_20, 3_4_1, 3_4_7, 3_13_1, 3_13_2, 3_13_5, 3_13_6 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_4_21, ac_17_b, ac_17_1, ac_17_4_a, ac_17_9, ac_17_10, cm_2_a, cm_2_2, cm_6_a, cm_7_b, cm_8_6, cm_9_b, sc_7_5, sc_7_7, sc_7_11, sc_7_12, sc_7_16, sc_7_21, sc_7_24_b, sc_7_25, sc_7_26, sc_7_27, sc_7_28, sc_7_a, sc_7_c •CISA: your-data-2 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ae_1, ac_3, ac_5, pt_4 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3, annex_i_5_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g, 11.10-k •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_312_e_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-17, cm-2, sc-7

FAIL medium ec2 us-west-2 ec2_networkacl_allow_ingress_any_port Ensure no Network ACLs allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 to any port. acl-d65266ae Network ACL acl-d65266ae has every port open to the Internet.

Even having a perimeter firewall, having network acls open allows any user or malware with vpc access to scan for well known and sensitive ports and gain access to instance.

Apply Zero Trust approach. Implement a process to scan and remediate unrestricted or overly permissive network acls. Recommended best practices is to narrow the definition for the minimum ports required.

FAIL medium ec2 ap-northeast-1 ec2_networkacl_allow_ingress_tcp_port_22 Ensure no Network ACLs allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 to SSH port 22 acl-9519d2f3 Network ACL acl-9519d2f3 has SSH port 22 open to the Internet.

Even having a perimeter firewall, having network acls open allows any user or malware with vpc access to scan for well known and sensitive ports and gain access to instance.

Apply Zero Trust approach. Implement a process to scan and remediate unrestricted or overly permissive network acls. Recommended best practices is to narrow the definition for the minimum ports required.

PASS high ec2 ap-northeast-1 ec2_securitygroup_allow_ingress_from_internet_to_any_port Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to any port. sg-d308faae Security group default (sg-d308faae) has not all ports open to the Internet.

If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.

Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

•CIS-1.5: 5.2, 5.3 •CIS-1.4: 5.2 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-2 •ENS-RD2022: mp.com.1.aws.sg.2

PASS high ec2 ap-northeast-2 ec2_securitygroup_allow_ingress_from_internet_to_any_port Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to any port. sg-bbb91ed7 Security group default (sg-bbb91ed7) has not all ports open to the Internet.

If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.

Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

•CIS-1.5: 5.2, 5.3 •CIS-1.4: 5.2 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-2 •ENS-RD2022: mp.com.1.aws.sg.2

PASS high ec2 ap-northeast-3 ec2_securitygroup_allow_ingress_from_internet_to_any_port Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to any port. sg-08c67673cc6cd2a82 Security group default (sg-08c67673cc6cd2a82) has not all ports open to the Internet.

If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.

Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

•CIS-1.5: 5.2, 5.3 •CIS-1.4: 5.2 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-2 •ENS-RD2022: mp.com.1.aws.sg.2

PASS high ec2 ap-south-1 ec2_securitygroup_allow_ingress_from_internet_to_any_port Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to any port. sg-029cf66f Security group default (sg-029cf66f) has not all ports open to the Internet.

If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.

Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

•CIS-1.5: 5.2, 5.3 •AWS-Audit-Manager-Control-Tower-Guardrails: 2.0.1 •CIS-1.4: 5.2 •PCI-3.2.1: ec2

PASS high ec2 us-east-2 ec2_securitygroup_allow_ingress_from_internet_to_tcp_port_3389 Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to port 3389. sg-926618ff Security group default (sg-926618ff) has not Microsoft RDP port 3389 open to the Internet.

If Security groups are not properly configured the attack surface is increased.

Use a Zero Trust approach. Narrow ingress traffic as much as possible. Consider north-south as well as east-west traffic.

•CIS-1.5: 5.2, 5.3 •AWS-Audit-Manager-Control-Tower-Guardrails: 2.0.1 •CIS-1.4: 5.2 •PCI-3.2.1: ec2

PASS high ec2 ap-northeast-1 ec2_securitygroup_default_restrict_traffic Ensure the default security group of every VPC restricts all traffic. sg-d308faae Default Security Group (sg-d308faae) is not open to the Internet.

Even having a perimeter firewall, having security groups open allows any user or malware with vpc access to scan for well known and sensitive ports and gain access to instance.

Apply Zero Trust approach. Implement a process to scan and remediate unrestricted or overly permissive security groups. Recommended best practices is to narrow the definition for the minimum ports required.

Even having a perimeter firewall, having security groups open allows any user or malware with vpc access to scan for well known and sensitive ports and gain access to instance.

Apply Zero Trust approach. Implement a process to scan and remediate unrestricted or overly permissive security groups. Recommended best practices is to narrow the definition for the minimum ports required.

PASS high iam us-east-1 iam_avoid_root_usage Avoid the use of the root accounts <root_account> Root user in the account wasn't accessed in the last 1 days.

The root account has unrestricted access to all resources in the AWS account. It is highly recommended that the use of this account be avoided.

Follow the remediation instructions of the Ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles recommendation.

•CIS-1.5: 1.7 •CIS-1.4: 1.7 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.2.aws.iam.4, op.acc.4.aws.iam.7

FAIL high iam us-east-1 iam_aws_attached_policy_no_administrative_privileges Ensure IAM AWS-Managed policies that allow full "*:*" administrative privileges are not attached AdministratorAccess AWS policy AdministratorAccess is attached and allows '*:*' administrative privileges

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

•SOC2: cc_1_3, cc_6_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, ac-6-10, ac-6, sc-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.16 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ac_3, ac_5, ac_6, sc_2 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-am-b-16, d3-pc-am-b-2, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6, d3-pc-im-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_4, 3_1_5, 3_1_6, 3_1_7, 3_4_6, 3_13_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_2_i_2, ac_3, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_5_b, ac_6, ac_6_2, ac_6_3, ac_6_10, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, mp_2, sc_23_3, sc_25 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1, ac_4, pt_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.4.aws.iam.1, op.acc.4.aws.iam.2, op.acc.4.aws.iam.9, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.8 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_3_i, 164_308_a_3_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_i, 164_308_a_4_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_312_a_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

•SOC2: cc_1_3, cc_6_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, ac-6-10, ac-6, sc-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.16 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ac_3, ac_5, ac_6, sc_2 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-am-b-16, d3-pc-am-b-2, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6, d3-pc-im-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_4, 3_1_5, 3_1_6, 3_1_7, 3_4_6, 3_13_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_2_i_2, ac_3, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_5_b, ac_6, ac_6_2, ac_6_3, ac_6_10, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, mp_2, sc_23_3, sc_25 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1, ac_4, pt_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.4.aws.iam.1, op.acc.4.aws.iam.2, op.acc.4.aws.iam.9, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.8 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_3_i, 164_308_a_3_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_i, 164_308_a_4_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_312_a_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3

Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

PASS high iam us-east-1 iam_aws_attached_policy_no_administrative_privileges Ensure IAM AWS-Managed policies that allow full "*:*" administrative privileges are not attached AWSElasticBeanstalkManagedUpdatesServiceRolePolicy AWS policy AWSElasticBeanstalkManagedUpdatesServiceRolePolicy is attached but does not allow '*:*' administrative privileges

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

•SOC2: cc_1_3, cc_6_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, ac-6-10, ac-6, sc-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.16 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ac_3, ac_5, ac_6, sc_2 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-am-b-16, d3-pc-am-b-2, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6, d3-pc-im-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_4, 3_1_5, 3_1_6, 3_1_7, 3_4_6, 3_13_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_2_i_2, ac_3, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_5_b, ac_6, ac_6_2, ac_6_3, ac_6_10, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, mp_2, sc_23_3, sc_25 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1, ac_4, pt_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.4.aws.iam.1, op.acc.4.aws.iam.2, op.acc.4.aws.iam.9, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.8 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_3_i, 164_308_a_3_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_i, 164_308_a_4_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_312_a_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3

PASS high iam us-east-1 iam_aws_attached_policy_no_administrative_privileges Ensure IAM AWS-Managed policies that allow full "*:*" administrative privileges are not attached AWSGlobalAcceleratorSLRPolicy AWS policy AWSGlobalAcceleratorSLRPolicy is attached but does not allow '*:*' administrative privileges

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

•SOC2: cc_1_3, cc_6_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, ac-6-10, ac-6, sc-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.16 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ac_3, ac_5, ac_6, sc_2 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-am-b-16, d3-pc-am-b-2, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6, d3-pc-im-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_4, 3_1_5, 3_1_6, 3_1_7, 3_4_6, 3_13_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_2_i_2, ac_3, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_5_b, ac_6, ac_6_2, ac_6_3, ac_6_10, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, mp_2, sc_23_3, sc_25 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1, ac_4, pt_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.4.aws.iam.1, op.acc.4.aws.iam.2, op.acc.4.aws.iam.9, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.8 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_3_i, 164_308_a_3_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_i, 164_308_a_4_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_312_a_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

PASS high iam us-east-1 iam_aws_attached_policy_no_administrative_privileges Ensure IAM AWS-Managed policies that allow full "*:*" administrative privileges are not attached CloudFrontFullAccess AWS policy CloudFrontFullAccess is attached but does not allow '*:*' administrative privileges

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

PASS high iam us-east-1 iam_customer_attached_policy_no_administrative_privileges Ensure IAM Customer-Managed policies that allow full "*:*" administrative privileges are not attached AWSLambdaEdgeExecutionRole-163c48c6-8ec9-4e08-8add-f07dad236e9c Custom policy AWSLambdaEdgeExecutionRole-163c48c6-8ec9-4e08-8add-f07dad236e9c is attached but does not allow '*:*' administrative privileges

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

•SOC2: cc_1_3, cc_6_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, ac-6-10, ac-6, sc-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.16 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ac_3, ac_5, ac_6, sc_2 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-am-b-16, d3-pc-am-b-2, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6, d3-pc-im-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_4, 3_1_5, 3_1_6, 3_1_7, 3_4_6, 3_13_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_2_i_2, ac_3, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_5_b, ac_6, ac_6_2, ac_6_3, ac_6_10, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, mp_2, sc_23_3, sc_25 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1, ac_4, pt_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.4.aws.iam.1, op.acc.4.aws.iam.2, op.acc.4.aws.iam.9, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.8 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_3_i, 164_308_a_3_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_i, 164_308_a_4_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_312_a_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

•SOC2: cc_1_3, cc_6_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, ac-6-10, ac-6, sc-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.16 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ac_3, ac_5, ac_6, sc_2 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-am-b-16, d3-pc-am-b-2, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6, d3-pc-im-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_4, 3_1_5, 3_1_6, 3_1_7, 3_4_6, 3_13_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_2_i_2, ac_3, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_5_b, ac_6, ac_6_2, ac_6_3, ac_6_10, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, mp_2, sc_23_3, sc_25 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1, ac_4, pt_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.4.aws.iam.1, op.acc.4.aws.iam.2, op.acc.4.aws.iam.9, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.8 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_3_i, 164_308_a_3_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_i, 164_308_a_4_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_312_a_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3

PASS high iam us-east-1 iam_customer_attached_policy_no_administrative_privileges Ensure IAM Customer-Managed policies that allow full "*:*" administrative privileges are not attached ft_VantaAdditionalPermissions •created_by=fonto/jva •scope=it/security Custom policy ft_VantaAdditionalPermissions is attached but does not allow '*:*' administrative privileges

IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is; granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks instead of allowing full administrative privileges. Providing full administrative privileges instead of restricting to the minimum set of permissions that the user is required to do exposes the resources to potentially unwanted actions.

It is more secure to start with a minimum set of permissions and grant additional permissions as necessary; rather than starting with permissions that are too lenient and then trying to tighten them later. List policies an analyze if permissions are the least possible to conduct business activities.

•SOC2: cc_1_3, cc_6_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, ac-6-10, ac-6, sc-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.16 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ac_3, ac_5, ac_6, sc_2 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-am-b-16, d3-pc-am-b-2, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6, d3-pc-im-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_4, 3_1_5, 3_1_6, 3_1_7, 3_4_6, 3_13_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_2_i_2, ac_3, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_5_b, ac_6, ac_6_2, ac_6_3, ac_6_10, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, mp_2, sc_23_3, sc_25 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1, ac_4, pt_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.4.aws.iam.1, op.acc.4.aws.iam.2, op.acc.4.aws.iam.9, op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.8 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_3_i, 164_308_a_3_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_i, 164_308_a_4_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_312_a_1 •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3

FAIL medium iam us-east-1 iam_disable_45_days_credentials Ensure credentials unused for 45 days or greater are disabled juan User juan has not logged in to the console in the past 45 days.

To increase the security of your AWS account; remove IAM user credentials (that is; passwords and access keys) that are not needed. For example; when users leave your organization or no longer need AWS access.

Find the credentials that they were using and ensure that they are no longer operational. Ideally; you delete credentials if they are no longer needed. You can always recreate them at a later date if the need arises. At the very least; you should change the password or deactivate the access keys so that the former users no longer have access.

•CIS-1.5: 1.12 •CIS-1.4: 1.12

PASS medium iam us-east-1 iam_disable_45_days_credentials Ensure credentials unused for 45 days or greater are disabled <root_account> User <root_account> does not have access keys.

To increase the security of your AWS account; remove IAM user credentials (that is; passwords and access keys) that are not needed. For example; when users leave your organization or no longer need AWS access.

Find the credentials that they were using and ensure that they are no longer operational. Ideally; you delete credentials if they are no longer needed. You can always recreate them at a later date if the need arises. At the very least; you should change the password or deactivate the access keys so that the former users no longer have access.

•CIS-1.5: 1.12 •CIS-1.4: 1.12

PASS medium iam us-east-1 iam_disable_45_days_credentials Ensure credentials unused for 45 days or greater are disabled juan User juan does not have unused access keys for 45 days.

To increase the security of your AWS account; remove IAM user credentials (that is; passwords and access keys) that are not needed. For example; when users leave your organization or no longer need AWS access.

Find the credentials that they were using and ensure that they are no longer operational. Ideally; you delete credentials if they are no longer needed. You can always recreate them at a later date if the need arises. At the very least; you should change the password or deactivate the access keys so that the former users no longer have access.

•CIS-1.5: 1.12 •CIS-1.4: 1.12

PASS critical iam us-east-1 iam_no_root_access_key Ensure no root account access key exists <root_account> User <root_account> does not have access keys.

The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. AWS Access Keys provide programmatic access to a given AWS account. It is recommended that all access keys associated with the root account be removed. Removing access keys associated with the root account limits vectors by which the account can be compromised. Removing the root access keys encourages the creation and use of role based accounts that are least privileged.

Use the credential report to that the user and ensure the access_key_1_active and access_key_2_active fields are set to FALSE.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, ac-6-10, ac-6, ia-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.4 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.4 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ac_3, ac_6_10, ac_6 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-8 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_4, 3_1_5, 3_1_6, 3_1_7, 3_4_6 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_6, ac_6_2, ac_6_10, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, ia_2, ia_4_b, ia_4_4, ia_4_8, ia_5_8, mp_2, sc_23_3, sc_25 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1, ac_4, pt_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.4.aws.iam.7 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g, 11.200 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_3_i, 164_308_a_3_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_312_a_2_i •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3, ia-2

FAIL medium iam us-east-1 iam_password_policy_minimum_length_14 Ensure IAM password policy requires minimum length of 14 or greater password_policy Password policy cannot be found

Password policies are used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure password are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require minimum length of 14 or greater.

Ensure "Minimum password length" is checked under "Password Policy".

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-2-3, ac-5-c, ia-2, ia-5-1-a-d-e, ia-5-4 •CIS-1.5: 1.8 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.8 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-6, d3-pc-am-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_5_7 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_3_a, ac_2_3_b, ac_2_3_c, ac_2_3_d, ac_2_3, ac_2_d_1, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_7_4, ac_7_4_a, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, cm_12_b, ia_4_d, ia_5, ia_5_b, ia_5_c, ia_5_d, ia_5_f, ia_5_h, ia_5_1_f, ia_5_1_g, ia_5_1_h, ia_5_1_h, ia_5_18_a, ia_5_18_b, ia_8_2_b, ma_4_c, sc_23_3 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-4 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.6.r1.aws.iam.1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g, 11.200, 11.300-b •HIPAA: 164_308_a_5_ii_d •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ia-2

FAIL medium iam us-east-1 iam_password_policy_reuse_24 Ensure IAM password policy prevents password reuse: 24 or greater password_policy Password policy cannot be found

Password policies are used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure password are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy prevents at least password reuse of 24 or greater.

Ensure "Number of passwords to remember" is set to 24.

•CIS-1.5: 1.9 •CIS-1.4: 1.9 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2_1, ac_2, ia_2, ia_5_1, ia_5_4 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_5_5, 3_5_6, 3_5_7, 3_5_8 •GDPR: article_25 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.6.r1.aws.iam.1 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_2 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_308_a_5_ii_d, 164_312_d

PASS low iam us-east-1 iam_policy_attached_only_to_group_or_roles Ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles juan User juan has no inline or attached policies

By default IAM users; groups; and roles have no access to AWS resources. IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users; groups; or roles. It is recommended that IAM policies be applied directly to groups and roles but not users. Assigning privileges at the group or role level reduces the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. Reducing access management complexity may in-turn reduce opportunity for a principal to inadvertently receive or retain excessive privileges.

Remove any policy attached directly to the user. Use groups or roles instead.

•SOC2: cc_1_3 •FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ac-3, ac-5-c, sc-2 •CIS-1.5: 1.15 •CIS-1.4: 1.15 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_6 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-1, d3-pc-im-b-7 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_4_6 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_2_6, ac_2_i_2, ac_3, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_7, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_6, ac_6_3, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, mp_2, sc_23_3 •ENS-RD2022: op.exp.8.r4.aws.ct.8 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_7_1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ac-3

FAIL critical iam us-east-1 iam_root_hardware_mfa_enabled Ensure only hardware MFA is enabled for the root account root MFA is not enabled for root account.

The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. MFA adds an extra layer of protection on top of a user name and password. With MFA enabled when a user signs in to an AWS website they will be prompted for their user name and password as well as for an authentication code from their AWS MFA device. For Level 2 it is recommended that the root account be protected with only a hardware MFA.

Using IAM console navigate to Dashboard and expand Activate MFA on your root account.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ia-2-1-2, ia-2-1 •CIS-1.5: 1.6 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.6 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ia_2_1, ia_2_11 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-15, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_5_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_3_2, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_7_4, ac_7_4_a, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, ia_2_1, ia_2_2, ia_2_6, ia_2_6_a, ia_2_8, sc_23_3 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-2 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_3, ac_7 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.6.r4.aws.iam.1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g, 11.200 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_3_ii_a, 164_312_d •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ia-2

FAIL critical iam us-east-1 iam_root_mfa_enabled Ensure MFA is enabled for the root account <root_account> MFA is not enabled for root account.

The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. MFA adds an extra layer of protection on top of a user name and password. With MFA enabled when a user signs in to an AWS website they will be prompted for their user name and password as well as for an authentication code from their AWS MFA device. When virtual MFA is used for root accounts it is recommended that the device used is NOT a personal device but rather a dedicated mobile device (tablet or phone) that is managed to be kept charged and secured independent of any individual personal devices. (non-personal virtual MFA) This lessens the risks of losing access to the MFA due to device loss / trade-in or if the individual owning the device is no longer employed at the company.

Using IAM console navigate to Dashboard and expand Activate MFA on your root account.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ia-2-1-2, ia-2-1 •CIS-1.5: 1.5 •AWS-Audit-Manager-Control-Tower-Guardrails: 3.0.3 •CIS-1.4: 1.5 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2, ia_2_1, ia_2_11 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-15, d3-pc-am-b-3, d3-pc-am-b-6 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_5_2, 3_5_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_3_2, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_7_4, ac_7_4_a, ac_24, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, ia_2_1, ia_2_2, ia_2_6, ia_2_6_a, ia_2_8, sc_23_3 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-2, booting-up-thing-to-do-first-2 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_3, ac_7 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.6.r2.aws.iam.1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g, 11.200 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_3_ii_a, 164_312_d •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ia-2

PASS medium iam us-east-1 iam_rotate_access_key_90_days Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less <root_account> User <root_account> does not have access keys older than 90 days.

Access keys consist of an access key ID and secret access key which are used to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. AWS users need their own access keys to make programmatic calls to AWS from the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI)- Tools for Windows PowerShell- the AWS SDKs- or direct HTTP calls using the APIs for individual AWS services. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.

Use the credential report to ensure access_key_X_last_rotated is less than 90 days ago.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j •CIS-1.5: 1.14 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.14 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ac_2_1, ac_2 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-6 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, sc_23_3 •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_1 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.6.aws.iam.2, op.acc.6.aws.iam.3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g, 11.200, 11.300-b •HIPAA: 164_308_a_3_ii_c, 164_308_a_4_ii_c, 164_308_a_5_ii_d •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2

FAIL medium iam us-east-1 iam_rotate_access_key_90_days Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less juan User juan has not rotated access key 1 in over 90 days (518 days).

Access keys consist of an access key ID and secret access key which are used to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. AWS users need their own access keys to make programmatic calls to AWS from the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI)- Tools for Windows PowerShell- the AWS SDKs- or direct HTTP calls using the APIs for individual AWS services. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.

•CIS-1.5: 1.17 •CIS-1.4: 1.17 •GDPR: article_25 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.3.r1.aws.iam.1

PASS high iam us-east-1 iam_user_mfa_enabled_console_access Ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password. <root_account> User <root_account> does not have Console Password enabled.

Unauthorized access to this critical account if password is not secure or it is disclosed in any way.

Enable MFA for users account. MFA is a simple best practice that adds an extra layer of protection on top of your user name and password. Recommended to use hardware keys over virtual MFA.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: ac-2-1, ac-2-f, ac-2-j, ia-2-1-2, ia-2-1 •CIS-1.5: 1.10 •AWS-Audit-Manager-Control-Tower-Guardrails: 3.0.1, 3.0.2 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: iam •CIS-1.4: 1.10 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: ia_2_1, ia_2_2, ia_2_11 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-15, d3-pc-am-b-6 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_1_1, 3_1_2, 3_1_14, 3_5_2, 3_5_3 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: ac_2_1, ac_3_2, ac_3_3, ac_3_3_a, ac_3_3_b_1, ac_3_3_b_2, ac_3_3_b_3, ac_3_3_b_4, ac_3_3_b_5, ac_3_3_c, ac_3_4, ac_3_4_a, ac_3_4_b, ac_3_4_c, ac_3_4_d, ac_3_4_e, ac_3_8, ac_3_12_a, ac_3_13, ac_3_15_a, ac_3_15_b, ac_4_28, ac_7_4, ac_7_4_a, ac_24, cm_5_1_a, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, ia_2_1, ia_2_2, ia_2_6, ia_2_6_a, ia_2_8, sc_23_3 •PCI-3.2.1: iam •GDPR: article_25 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-surroundings-2, booting-up-thing-to-do-first-2 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ac_3, ac_7 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.6.r2.aws.iam.1, op.acc.6.r4.aws.iam.1, op.acc.6.r8.aws.iam.1 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-d, 11.10-g, 11.200 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_3_ii_a, 164_312_a_1, 164_312_d •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: ac-2, ia-2

PASS medium iam us-east-1 iam_user_no_setup_initial_access_key Do not setup access keys during initial user setup for all IAM users that have a console password <root_account> User <root_account> does not have access keys or uses the access keys configured

AWS console defaults the checkbox for creating access keys to enabled. This results in many access keys being generated unnecessarily. In addition to unnecessary credentials; it also generates unnecessary management work in auditing and rotating these keys. Requiring that additional steps be taken by the user after their profile has been created will give a stronger indication of intent that access keys are (a) necessary for their work and (b) once the access key is established on an account that the keys may be in use somewhere in the organization.

From the IAM console: generate credential report and disable not required keys.

•CIS-1.5: 1.11 •CIS-1.4: 1.11 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.6.aws.iam.4

PASS medium iam us-east-1 iam_user_no_setup_initial_access_key Do not setup access keys during initial user setup for all IAM users that have a console password juan User juan does not have access keys or uses the access keys configured

AWS console defaults the checkbox for creating access keys to enabled. This results in many access keys being generated unnecessarily. In addition to unnecessary credentials; it also generates unnecessary management work in auditing and rotating these keys. Requiring that additional steps be taken by the user after their profile has been created will give a stronger indication of intent that access keys are (a) necessary for their work and (b) once the access key is established on an account that the keys may be in use somewhere in the organization.

From the IAM console: generate credential report and disable not required keys.

Access Keys could be lost or stolen. It creates a critical risk.

Avoid using long lived access keys.

•CIS-1.5: 1.13 •CIS-1.4: 1.13 •ENS-RD2022: op.acc.6.aws.iam.1

PASS low rds ap-southeast-2 rds_instance_minor_version_upgrade_enabled Ensure RDS instances have minor version upgrade enabled. humaniti-db RDS Instance humaniti-db has minor version upgrade enabled.

Auto Minor Version Upgrade is a feature that you can enable to have your database automatically upgraded when a new minor database engine version is available. Minor version upgrades often patch security vulnerabilities and fix bugs and therefore should be applied.

Enable auto minor version upgrade for all databases and environments.

•CIS-1.5: 2.3.2 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: rds •FFIEC: d3-cc-pm-b-1, d3-cc-pm-b-3 •CISA: your-systems-2, booting-up-thing-to-do-first-3 •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_6

FAIL critical rds ap-southeast-2 rds_instance_no_public_access Ensure there are no Public Accessible RDS instances. humaniti-db RDS Instance humaniti-db is set as Publicly Accessible.

Publicly accessible databases could expose sensitive data to bad actors.

Using an AWS Config rule check for RDS public instances periodically and check there is a business reason for it.

PASS medium s3 ap-southeast-2 s3_bucket_default_encryption Check if S3 buckets have default encryption (SSE) enabled or use a bucket policy to enforce it. aws-sam-cli-managed-default-samclisourcebucket-xqyopx35sna3 •aws:cloudformation:stack-name=aws-sam-cli-managed-default •aws:cloudformation:logical-id=SamCliSourceBucket •ManagedStackSource=AwsSamCli •aws:cloudformation:stack-id=arn:aws:cloudformation:ap-southeast-2:051355080838:stack/aws-sam-cli-managed-default/de205390-d805-11ed-a641-0652b6293ed6 S3 Bucket aws-sam-cli-managed-default-samclisourcebucket-xqyopx35sna3 has Server Side Encryption with aws:kms.

•FedRamp-Moderate-Revision-4: sc-13, sc-28 •CIS-1.5: 2.1.1 •AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices: s3 •CIS-1.4: 2.1.1 •NIST-800-53-Revision-4: sc_28 •FFIEC: d3-pc-am-b-12 •NIST-800-171-Revision-2: 3_3_8, 3_5_10, 3_13_11, 3_13_16 •NIST-800-53-Revision-5: au_9_3, cm_6_a, cm_9_b, cp_9_d, cp_9_8, pm_11_b, sc_8_3, sc_8_4, sc_13_a, sc_16_1, sc_28_1, si_19_4 •PCI-3.2.1: s3 •GDPR: article_32 •CISA: your-systems-3, your-data-1, your-data-2 •NIST-CSF-1.1: ds_1 •ENS-RD2022: mp.si.2.aws.s3.1 •GxP-EU-Annex-11: 7.1-data-storage-damage-protection •RBI-Cyber-Security-Framework: annex_i_1_3 •GxP-21-CFR-Part-11: 11.10-c, 11.30 •HIPAA: 164_308_a_1_ii_b, 164_308_a_4_ii_a, 164_312_a_2_iv, 164_312_c_1, 164_312_c_2, 164_312_e_2_ii •FedRAMP-Low-Revision-4: sc-13

PASS medium s3 ap-southeast-2 s3_bucket_default_encryption Check if S3 buckets have default encryption (SSE) enabled or use a bucket policy to enforce it. dev-backend-api-alt-elb S3 Bucket dev-backend-api-alt-elb has Server Side Encryption with AES256.

Amazon S3 default encryption provides a way to set the default encryption behavior for an S3 bucket. This will ensure data-at-rest is encrypted.

Ensure that S3 buckets has encryption at rest enabled.

PASS medium s3 ap-southeast-2 s3_bucket_level_public_access_block Check S3 Bucket Level Public Access Block. aws-sam-cli-managed-default-samclisourcebucket-xqyopx35sna3 •aws:cloudformation:stack-name=aws-sam-cli-managed-default •aws:cloudformation:logical-id=SamCliSourceBucket •ManagedStackSource=AwsSamCli •aws:cloudformation:stack-id=arn:aws:cloudformation:ap-southeast-2:051355080838:stack/aws-sam-cli-managed-default/de205390-d805-11ed-a641-0652b6293ed6 Block Public Access is configured for the S3 Bucket aws-sam-cli-managed-default-samclisourcebucket-xqyopx35sna3.

Public access policies may be applied to sensitive data buckets.

You can enable Public Access Block at the bucket level to prevent the exposure of your data stored in S3.

•CIS-1.5: 2.1.5 •CIS-1.4: 2.1.5

You can enable Public Access Block at the bucket level to prevent the exposure of your data stored in S3.

You can enable Public Access Block at the bucket level to prevent the exposure of your data stored in S3.

•CIS-1.5: 2.1.5 •CIS-1.4: 2.1.5

PASS medium s3 ap-southeast-2 s3_bucket_level_public_access_block Check S3 Bucket Level Public Access Block. humaniti-etl Block Public Access is configured for the S3 Bucket humaniti-etl.

Public access policies may be applied to sensitive data buckets.

You can enable Public Access Block at the bucket level to prevent the exposure of your data stored in S3.

•CIS-1.5: 2.1.5 •CIS-1.4: 2.1.5

You can enable Public Access Block at the bucket level to prevent the exposure of your data stored in S3.
